Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has achieved the record of becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo, completing a 702-mile trek in 38 days through harsh Antarctic conditions. He pulled a sled carrying supplies and navigated through 150mph winds, temperatures of -50°C, and crevasse-filled terrain. His journey began at Hercules Inlet, where the ground is riddled with crevasses, and he faced the challenge of traveling alone, without the safety of being roped to a teammate.

Sears, who is the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, experienced a particularly challenging day just 38km (24 miles) from his destination on Christmas Eve. He hit a wall midway through the day, but managed to push through with some rest and motivation from his iPod. He even hung his socks as makeshift stockings on Christmas Eve, hoping Santa wouldn't miss him.

On Christmas Day, Sears reached the South Pole, arriving a week earlier than expected. He wrote that he was "absolutely chuffed to pieces" and looked forward to the experience sinking in. He is currently waiting for a plane to take him back to Union Glacier, expressing that the experience has been overwhelming due to his isolation for nearly six weeks.

Sears's expedition has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust, an organization that helps rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which was destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. His mother-in-law, Judy Murray, congratulated him on Twitter. The Guinness Book of Records is yet to confirm whether Sears's feat will make it into the record books.

Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. This superheated ice persists in the fish's bodies for extended periods, potentially causing long-term damage.

This means that notothenioids carry ice crystals around in their veins for most of their lives, a risky proposition that could potentially cause life-threatening traffic jams in small capillaries.

The team also found that the highest concentration of ice crystals resides in the fish's spleens, leading to the hypothesis that the spleen may be trying to filter out the ice crystals to prevent them from causing problems in other parts of the body. The West Coast of North America is experiencing a severe decline in the population of Pacific sardines, a crucial forage fish that supports a diverse marine ecosystem. This decline has been attributed to a combination of factors, including a naturally occurring climate cycle known as the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, which has brought cold, nutrient-rich water to the West Coast, and overfishing. The decline in sardine population is causing concern for various species of seabirds, whales, sharks, dolphins, and commercially important fish such as salmon and tuna that rely on sardines as a major food source.

The Pacific Fishery Management Council, which manages fishing in federal waters off California, Oregon, and Washington, is being urged to set conservative catch limits on sardines and prohibit unregulated fishing on forage fish such as sand lance, saury, and lanternfish that are not currently managed or monitored. The decline in sardine population is also affecting the livelihood of commercial fishermen, with many reporting a significant decrease in catches.

The decline in sardine population is particularly concerning because sardines are a staple of the commercial purse-seine fishing on the West Coast. If the sardine population does not recover soon, experts warn that the West Coast's marine ecosystem could suffer for years, and fishermen could face long-term consequences.

The decline in sardine population is also causing concern for marine predators such as brown pelicans, sea lions, and other seabirds that rely on sardines for food. In 2013, 1,600 malnourished sea lion pups washed up along beaches from Santa Barbara to San Diego, with scientists attributing the malnourishment to a scarcity of prey, particularly sardines.

The sardine fishery has a history of volatility, with populations fluctuating widely. The November 2013 population estimate of 378,000 tons is the lowest in more than a decade, far below the peak of 1.5 million tons estimated in 2000. Geological records indicate that the unfished sardine population fluctuated between a low of 400,000 tons to as much as 16 million tons.

For further information

Neither species can turn to anchovies as an alternative food source, as they normally would, because their numbers are also down. Fishermen, too, are affected; they're not allowed to catch as many sardines (harvest maximums have been dramatically cut)—and they often can't find any to catch (the LA Times follows one boat that caught zero fish in a 12-hour outing). So what's going on? Sardine populations often experience wild swings, booming when conditions are good and then dropping sharply when conditions shift. After the last bad collapse, which happened after a massive boom in the 1940s, sardine fishing was halted for 18 years beginning in the 1960s, and though the population bounced back in the 1980s, it was never the same. Scientists now, as then, aren't sure how to divide the blame between ocean conditions (the Pacific Decadal Oscillation, a climate cycle, has brought cold, sardine-unfriendly water to the area) and overfishing. Last month, Pew Charitable Trusts warned that dozens of species, including whales, sharks, dolphins, salmon, and tuna, could feel an impact.

The study says the removal of lymph nodes from the armpit—a common, painful procedure that carries side effects of its own—isn't necessary for about 20% of patients in early stages of the disease. "The discovery turns standard medical practice on its head," declares the Times. “This is such a radical change in thought that it’s been hard for many people to get their heads around it,” says a doctor at Sloan-Kettering and an author of the study. The hospital has already changed its treatment procedures accordingly. The full study, published in the Journal of American Medicine, is here.
